headline: Boston Scientific Review
pros: There can be great coworkers that you get along well with and for me as time went by the amount of coworkers hard to get along with become less and less. If you have a great attitude then the only thing you need to worry about to not be hard for others to get along with you is to have a high output. That's where the cons come in.
cons:
1. Always need to hit goals. My department and shift in particular is short staffed so we need to constantly do overtime whether it's staying extra hours and/or working the weekend to hit our monthly goals. We are continually pushed to have higher outputs even though we are completely above our staffing goal. If it's any worse than this you can expect to work holidays as well. For high-output-experienced-workers this hits us hard because we have to constantly do everything. You'd be hard pressed to know that attendance is king when it comes to getting your raise and having experience and high output does you no good. It's even worse that it doesn't get you a promotion either. Makes you think why you're going so fast for besides the fact that you may not want to do overtime.

2. Management is bad. We are constantly told to do more than 1 job simultaneously and in a fast paced environment it becomes extremely tiring . It's 1 person doing a 2-3 person job getting paid 1 person. Great for the employer but horrible for the employee. Management also gets so stressed they lay the anger and frustration on you. I know because they tell us sometimes but that never justifies. It's almost everyday. They also know that you cannot do anything and no one will care if you did. There has been multiple reportings of people to Supervisors, Managers, and Human Resources but they do not do anything about the person being reported. Especially so when that person is a Supervisor or higher (including a Production Coordinator which is 1 step below a Supervisor).

3. Opportunities for advancement. They hire more people from the outside than they hire/promote people from inside the company. This makes it very hard for anyone as a Production Builder or similar to advance their career. You will not be given a chance to learn something new because they want someone who already knows a bit to do the job even if you are a passionate, hard worker and fast learner.

4. Salary. For Production Builders the salary is capped at $25/hr as a Production Builder III. Which requires at least 7 years of experience etc. Keep in mind that we do a 2-3 person job so getting $25/hr wouldn't cut it anyways. The base pay for a contractor is $17.50/hr, doing a 2 person job, would be $35/hr but you're getting nowhere near that. No great bonuses either, sometimes you may get anywhere between a $5-$50 gift card. It's definitely not occasional, just whenever management "feels" we're doing too much but they also have to approve of it with their superiors too which decreases the chances of getting it depending if your higher ups want to or not. It's nice to be rewarded, but you won't get much here.

headline: Losing Its Focus on People
pros: Boston Scientific has an exceptionally strong CEO and Executive Team that has enabled outstanding growth over the last decade, and they have aligned the company around a mission that is truly patient focused.    The employees are bright, dedicated, and collaborative.   Together they create a culture which is friendly, inclusive, and focused on making a difference the lives of patients.
cons: Over the last three years, the organization has seemingly lost its way around the importance of people development.   Particularly in the area of HR, they have seemingly tolerated very weak and inappropriate leadership; they have dismantled one of the best global talent management functions in the country and abandoned their approach to engagement, internal development, best in class capabilities, and work/life balance.     Employees, and especially high potentials, are extremely frustrated with the lack of leadership, sponsorship,  and career development and are ready to leave the organization.   Most are finding their roles more tactical than strategic and are seeing such an increase in demands that they cannot maintain a reasonable balance of work/life.  Most are seeing an org structure which is so lean that they cannot begin to meet the real needs of their clients.

headline: If your company is acquired, look for work (YMMV)
pros:
If you are at a main company site (I believe mostly in Minnesota) or at a site they decide to keep, it appears to be a well run, well funded place with classes and conferences to help you stay current.  

If you are at an acquired company, they will tell you how valued you are.  You may get continued employment for some time, and they provide some outplacement support and severance when they lay you off.
cons:
Hunter-gatherer, with companies and products as prey.

If you are at a company that is acquired and don't want to move to Minnesota (extremes of -40°F and 110°F humid), start looking for work.  They come in friendly, learn about your products, then transfer the profitable ones to Minnesota or offshore, kill any that don't have high enough ROI, and lay everyone off with various amounts of warning.

Not sure whether you will get to design anything new.  If there is any next-generation product development or work to keep them updated, I am not aware of it.

cons: Compensation is not competitive with the current medical device sales market, and achieving plan is consistently made to be an aggressive challenge- Sales plan is laid out on a quarterly basis, which prohibits reps from celebrating their "wins" for longer than a month or two before they are baked into their following quarter. High-performing younger employees are at a disadvantage here, as the red-tape is ever-present. The company will allow you take take on increased responsibility if you are performing, but do not expect to be compensated at the same level as your tenured peers.

headline: IT technical staff
pros: Large organization that affords opportunities for internal mobility, whether one desires technical or managerial track. Above-average work/life balance, except for stingy vacation days given to new employees. From a tech standpoint, company is so big that there is no shortage of interesting work.
cons: Every company I've worked for views IT spending as a necessary evil, but BSC C-level management takes it to another level. About half of the 1000 IT employees are Indian employees of Tata Consulting Services, with the ones in the US on the problematic H1B visa program. Amidst an otherwise banner year for BSC financials, an IT layoff of US-based employees happened and we were told outright it was because not enough (expensive) US employees left through retirement or otherwise. That was disgusting, but it happened amidst the obvious failure of Indian outsourcing in BSC and against strong industry trends away from it (google it). Non-IT employees rightly associate IT with incompetent and unhelpful Indian employees and heavy users regularly go around the help desk to competent US employees. Ironically, the most "successful" recent initiatives were adding IT bars (like Apple's Genius bars) at major US sites so employees could get competent help, and stop giving such gawd-awful satisfaction rankings to IT's Indian help desk. A not-so-advertised related "success" was the introduction of a special US-based help desk for sales staff, so this vocal, high-profile group didn't have to ever deal with Indians. Gobs of non-technical US interns that seem to get hired at high rates to fill quotas while US/EU technical staff trudge along under constant hiring freezes, until absolutely needed, then told to hire non-US only.

headline: A promising future
pros:
I've been employed at BSCI for about 6 years. During that time, the company has undergone significant changes - becoming leaner and more focused on it's core product offerings. As a result, the company's stock has appreciated significantly as new products have been launched successfully. This has greatly benefited the employees who participate in the stock purchase plan - where stock can be purchased at a discount twice each year. In addition, the company has funded an attractive yearly bonus, based on profitability. 

I have found the company to be very employee-friendly and a fun place to work. There are many perks that are offered during the year to build morale and loyalty.

Leadership was often changing in the beginning of my employment, but now we have talented, capable leaders who are stable in their positions. 

I feel that Boston Scientific has found it's footing and is moving forward with direction and purpose, providing excellent products for patients with serious health conditions and a promising future for its creative and dedicated employees.
cons: There have been regular reductions in the workforce over the time I've been employed, but now those seem to have abated. Unfortunately, these reductions were necessary and seem to have been a successful strategy in ensuring the profitability and future growth of the company.

headline: Typical, Bottom-Line Driven Corporation Only Growing Through Acquisition
pros: Fun and interesting employees, good benefits (holidays, vacation, med, dental, etc.). Adequate facilities/sites. Good quality products with a few acquired outliers that make a good difference in peoples' lives.
cons: Only lip-service to quality, and lack of understanding and seriousness regarding compliance with regulations. Middle-management fiddles while Rome burns, and upper-management accepts the sterilized data they're given. No room for excellent, experienced workers who understand the company and the industry, and they are systematically and periodically let go in waves of layoffs every year. Experienced workers are traded up for inexperienced workers at all professional levels/areas without the experience and history to call out their superiors' incompetence, and decision-making is based on cronyism. Business-as-usual is the mantra, and as is typical of large businesses since 2008 they are more interested in squeezing more hours and effort out of current employees to expand profits and bonuses than improving systems/processes or hiring additional workers for expansion.
